title: Putin accuses West of wanting Russians 'to kill each other' in aborted rebellion
description: In a televised address broadcast on Monday, June 26, the Russian president blasted organizers of a weekend revolt as "traitors" who played into the hands of Ukraine’s government and its allies. The rebellion by armed mercenaries was the greatest challenge yet to his two-decade rule.

title: EU auditors see 2030 climate and energy targets at risk
description: The European Court of Auditors warns that there is little evidence that the measures taken will be sufficient to achieve the targets for emissions reductions, renewable energies, and energy efficiency.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Japanese designers take on deconstruction and exploration
description: Whether it's a wave-patterned judo jacket at Kenzo, a dungaree-skirt hybrid at Sacai or mutant shoes at Comme des Garçons, three Japanese visions of menswear shook up the Paris catwalks.

title: On Bookstagram, young women find a social media haven: 'You're valued for personality, not looks'
description: While Instagram and TikTok are regularly criticized for their negative effect on young girls' mental health, online literary communities like BookTok and Bookstagram seem to offer them a space of expression where they can flourish, but under certain conditions.

title: Colorado Springs LGBTQ+ club mass killer gets life in prison
description: Anderson Lee Aldrich pleaded guilty to five counts of murder and 46 counts of attempted murder – one for each person inside Club Q on the night of the shooting.

title: Prigozhin says march on Moscow showed security problems in Russia
description: The leader of the Wagner mercenary group broke his silence in a Telegram audio message two days after staging a dramatic armed rebellion. He insisted he did not want to overthrow President Vladimir Putin.

title: Wagner's rebellion in Russia: Our Moscow correspondent answers readers' questions
description: After the Wagner Group's mutiny on Saturday, what are the consequences for Vladimir Putin's Russia? Journalist Benoît Vitkine answered questions from Le Monde's readers.

title: Guatemala: Two social democrats head to presidential election runoff
description: A former first lady and the son of an ex-president will go head-to-head in the August runoff, giving the Central American country its first leftist leader in more than a decade.

title: Uncontrollable rent rises put Turkish society under strain
description: Tenants and landlords are trapped by the economic crisis. The absence of effective state regulation is straining relations and affecting the social composition of major cities.

title: Kyiv welcomes instability in Russia and expects it to weaken Putin
description: After the Wagner rebellion, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Saturday, June 24, that 'the world saw that the bosses of Russia do not control anything.'

title: France extends police operation in overseas Mayotte
description: During a two-day visit to this Indian Ocean territory, Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin said he wanted to 'speed up the destruction' of substandard houses, and set the target of razing 1,250 of them by 'the end of the year.'

title: Wagner mutiny leaves trail of death and destruction in Rostov-on-Don and Voronezh
description: Briefly taking control of both Russian cities, Prigozhin's mercenaries caught the army off guard and deadly fighting broke out between insurgents and regular troops.

title: Wagner troops' departure 'a calculated risk' for Moscow
description: Yevgeny Prigozhin claimed to have 25,000 men in Ukraine, although since the capture of Bakhmut they had largely left the front line, so will his exile change the course of the conflict?

title: The Telegram founder's mysterious French passport
description: Pavel Durov, the head of the controversial messaging app, was granted French citizenship in 2021 through an exceptional and highly political procedure, a surprising choice on the part of the authorities – all of whom declined comment.

title: Belarus becomes unlikely refuge for Wagner's boss
description: President Alexander Lukashenko's surprise mediation to reach an agreement with Yevgeny Prigozhin dashed the Belarusian opposition's fleeting hopes of regime change in neighboring Russia, which holds the country under trusteeship.

title: Video: The Wagner Group's 24-hour power grab in Russia
description: After months of provocation, Wagner Group Chief Yevgeny Prigozhin finally went on the offensive against the Kremlin on June 23, before abruptly ending his rebellion.

title: Macron visits Marseille in bid to boost France's second city
description: Two years after launching a series of measures to turn around the port city's fortunes, the agenda for the president's visit includes security, schools, transport and housing.

title: Africa is among the stakes of Wagner insubordination
description: The militia group's spectacular presence on the African continent, since 2018, has fed Yevgeny Prigozhin's ambitions.

title: Vladimir Putin and Yevgeny Prigozhin: 20 years of collaboration
description: Before he became a threat, the businessman and warlord operated in the obscure areas of power that the Russian president is so fond of.

title: Greek conservative party emerges victorious from second general election
description: The center-right New Democracy party, led by incumbent Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, has won a second four-year term.

title: Moscow lifts Wagner mutiny security measures, defense minister appears on video
description: In a video released by his ministry, Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu was seen inspecting troops in Ukraine.

title: Putin avoids bloodshed, but at the cost of weakening his authority
description: The Russian president was forced to make peace with Yevgeny Prigozhin, whom he described as a "traitor," in a Russia he described as on the brink of "civil war"

title: 'After forty years of uninterrupted violence, the Middle East is engaging in a frenzy of political conversations'
description: Iran, Israel, Saudi Arabia, China and the United States. Diplomatic exchanges, not always official, are increasing in the region, notes Alain Frachon in his 'Le Monde' column.

title: Russia suffers legal setback in Australian embassy standoff
description: Australian lawmakers previously passed a law to prevent Russia from building an embassy close to the parliamentary precinct in Canberra.

title: Heat waves have caused nearly 33,000 deaths in France since 2014
description: In a report published on Friday, Santé Publique France estimated that heat was responsible for between 1,000 and 7,000 deaths each year, which could represent up to 9% of summer mortality.

title: UK and allies have trained 17,000 Ukrainian recruits
description: The initiative was opened by Britain and nine partner nations last year.

title: Kittens and crucifixes: Inside the world of Catholic influencers
description: A growing number of young people in France have been posting about their Catholic faith across TikTok, Instagram and YouTube – a trend the Church is following closely.

title: Frontex threatens to suspend its activities in Greece
description: At the board meeting of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, also known as Frontex, Athens was accused of multiple incidents of pushbacks of migrants, as well as inertia.

title: Greek conservatives sweep back to power as far-right parties make comeback
description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis will serve a second term as Prime Minister, as he is forced to contend with a growing far-right in the Greek Parliament.

title: West Africa's economic capitals threatened by rising sea levels
description: In Abidjan, Lagos and Lomé, some of the main economic assets are facing erosion and rising sea levels. And it's triggering huge costs for these developing cities.
